lines.content: AI tools were used as coding assistants to improve productivity and reduce
manual boilerplate coding. The tools were mainly used for:
- Generating initial drafts of command classes
- Suggesting refactoring improvements (e.g., reducing redundancy, improving SLAP)
- Explaining design decisions and debugging issues
- Improving commit messages and documentation wording
Most generated code was reviewed, modified, and adapted manually to fit
the project architecture and requirements. AI suggestions were not used
- AI significantly sped up boilerplate generation (e.g., command classes).
- AI was helpful for refactoring and improving code clarity.
- However, careful manual review was required to ensure correctness and
- AI occasionally suggested overly complex solutions, which were simplified manually.
Overall, AI tools improved development speed while still requiring
strong understanding of the codebase to integrate suggestions properly.
This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/trackr.Trackr.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run trackr.Trackr.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
What can I do for you?

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

Trackr is a chatbot that helps you manage your tasks. You can add todos, deadlines, and events, mark them as done, search for tasks, and update them—all from a simple chat interface.
Trackr can be used in two ways:
- **Command-line interface (CLI)** – Type commands in a terminal
- **Graphical user interface (GUI)** – Chat with Trackr in a window
2. **Using the JAR file** (after building with `./gradlew build`):
A window will open. Type your message in the text box at the bottom and press Enter or click Send.
1. **Using the JAR file** (after building with `./gradlew build`):
You will see a greeting in the terminal. Type commands and press Enter after each command.
- Words in `UPPER_CASE` are parameters to be supplied by you.
- e.g. in `todo DESCRIPTION`, `DESCRIPTION` is a parameter, such as `todo Buy groceries`.
- The `INDEX` is the task number shown in the list (1, 2, 3, …​).
- Extraneous parameters for commands that do not take them (such as `list` and `bye`) will be ignored.
- If you are using a PDF version of this document, take care when copying multi-line commands, as spaces around line breaks may be lost.
Shows all tasks in your list.
Adds a todo task with a description only (no date).
Adds a task with a description and due date.
Adds an event with a description, start date, and end date.
Marks the specified task as completed.
- `INDEX` must be a valid task number from the list (1, 2, 3, …​).
### Marking a task as not done: `unmark`
Marks the specified task as not yet completed.
Removes the specified task from the list.
Finds tasks whose descriptions contain the given keyword.
Updates an existing task. You can change the description, due date (for deadlines), or start/end dates (for events).
- At least one field (`/desc`, `/by`, or `/from`/`/to`) must be provided.
- For events, both `/from` and `/to` must be given together.
Task data is saved automatically after any command that changes the list. You do not need to save manually.
Task data is stored in `data/trackr.txt` (relative to where you run the application). Each line represents one task.
- `DONE` is `1` if the task is marked done, `0` otherwise.
- Fields are separated by ` | ` (space, pipe, space).
If you edit this file directly, ensure the format is correct. Invalid lines may cause errors when Trackr loads.
| `event` | `event DESCRIPTION /from DATE /to DATE` | Add an event |
| `unmark` | `unmark INDEX` | Mark task as not done |
| `update` | `update INDEX /desc DESC` or `/by DATE` or `/from DATE /to DATE` | Update a task |
